revision.comment: Just saw them used on Soyuz MS-09 mission 6/7/18
revision.text:
[[Image:Sokol KV2.JPG|thumb|200px|right|A KV-2 variant of the Sokol space suit displayed at the [[Technik Museum Speyer]], Germany (2008)]]
The '''Sokol space suit''', also known as the '''Sokol IVA suit''' or simply the '''Sokol''' ({{lang-ru|'''Cокол'''}}, ''Falcon''), is a type of [[Russia]]n [[space suit]], worn by all who fly on the [[Soyuz spacecraft]]. It was introduced in 1973 and is still used {{As of|2018|lc=on}}. The Sokol is described by its makers as a ''rescue suit''{{ref|abramov}} and it is not capable of being used outside the spacecraft in a spacewalk or [[extra-vehicular activity]]. Instead, its purpose is to keep the wearer alive in the event of an accidental depressurisation of the spacecraft. In this respect, it is similar to the [[Advance Crew Escape System Pressure Suit|ACES]] suit that was worn aboard [[NASA]]'s [[Space Shuttle]] during launch and landing.
== Description ==
The current version of the suit is the Sokol-KV2, manufactured by [[NPP Zvezda]] (НПП Звезда). It consists of an inner pressure layer of rubberised [[polycaprolactam]] and an outer layer of white nylon [[canvas]]. Boots are integrated with the suit but gloves are removable and attach by means of blue [[Anodising|anodised aluminium]] wrist couplings. The [[polycarbonate]] visor can open on hinges mounted near the ears and seals with an anodised aluminium clavicle flange when closed; the hood or 'soft helmet' folds when the visor is raised. The suit has four pockets and adjustment straps on the arms, legs, chest, and abdomen.
There is a suit pressure gauge on the left wrist. A mirror on an elastic wrist band is worn on the right—this helps the wearer see things that would otherwise be outside his or her field of view. During re-entry, an [[altimeter]] on a wrist strap may also be worn{{snd}} this gives an immediate check on cabin pressure and warns when to brace for touchdown (during the last phase of landing the cabin opens to the outside air.) A wristwatch is often worn as well, with an elastic wrist band replacing the strap so it may fit over the bulky suit glove. The watches are often privately purchased and a wide variety of Swiss and Russian models have been used.{{ref|sotherbys1}}{{ref|sotherbys2}}
Electrical cables are mounted on the right abdomen of the suit; on the left abdomen there are separate hoses for air and oxygen. Normally, an electric blower ventilates the suit with cabin air through the larger hose at the rate of {{convert|150|l|cuft|abbr=off}} per minute. If the cabin pressure drops below {{convert|600|hPa|atm psi|abbr=off}}, the air supply is automatically replaced with oxygen from pressurised bottles.{{ref|abramov}} at a rate of {{convert|22|l|cuft|abbr=off}} per minute.<ref name="ESA"/> Both air and oxygen exhaust through the blue pressure relief valve at the centre of the chest; this valve also regulates the pressure of the suit.
Effectively, the suit uses an open-circuit life support system that somewhat resembles [[Scuba set|scuba]] equipment. This has the advantage of simplicity; the disadvantage of a high rate of oxygen consumption is considered acceptable given that it is only intended for emergency use.
The suits weigh around {{convert|10|kg|lb}} and are described by those who have used them as a considerable encumbrance when worn on the ground.{{ref|sharman}} Despite this, they are intended to be worn for up to 30 hours in a pressurised environment or two hours in a vacuum. They can also float and have a neck dam that allows the visor to be raised in water without the risk of flooding the suit. However, Soyuz crews are provided with buoyancy aids and cold-water survival suits which would preferably be used if the Soyuz accidentally landed in water.{{ref|sharman}}{{ref|sotherbys1}}
{{As of|2002}}, a total of 309 flight suits had been made along with 135 training and testing suits.{{ref|abramov}}
== Operational use == [[Image:Expedition 16 suit up.jpg|thumb|right|[[Peggy Whitson]] wearing an inflated Sokol-KV2 spacesuit (2007)]] [[File:Expedition 47 Qualification Exams (NHQ201602250020).jpg|thumb|right|Sokol portable ventilation units]] Each Soyuz crew member is provided with a made-to-measure suit for flight although, from the numbers made, it appears that the suits provided for ground training are re-used. It is considered vital that the flight suit fits correctly and the wearer will spend two hours sitting in a launch couch with the suit inflated to make sure of this. Straps on the arms, legs and chest allow the fit to be adjusted slightly.
To don the suit, the two zips that make a 'V' on the chest are opened. Underneath, there is a large tubular opening in the inner pressure layer known as the ''appendix''. Legs go in first, followed by the arms into the sleeves and head into the helmet. When the suit is on, an airtight seal is made by tightly rolling up the appendix and securing it with strong elastic bands. The large bulge of the rolled-up appendix is secured under the V shaped flap in the suit's outer layer. When worn on the ground, the suit is attached to a portable ventilation unit —a hand-held device that supplies air to the suit, cooling it first with an ice filled heat exchanger. Grey leather outer boots are also worn on the ground; they protect the feet of the suit from damage and are removed before entering the spacecraft to avoid carrying debris into the cabin.
The suit is worn during launch and re-entry of the Soyuz spacecraft—the gloves are attached and the visor is sealed at these times. In an emergency, the suit pressure is usually maintained at 400 hPa (0.39 atm, 5.8 psi) above the ambient by the pressure relief valve. However, the suits only have a rudimentary pressure relief layer so they tend to balloon when inflated. Movement of the wearer becomes restricted, although it is still possible to function inside the capsule.
If more than limited movement is required, the pressure relief valve may be adjusted to a lower setting of 270 hPa (0.26 atm, 3.9 psi). Pure oxygen at this pressure will support life, but the setting is only intended for use in extreme emergencies;{{ref|sharman}} the risk of [[decompression sickness]] becomes significant if the wearer spends more than 15 minutes at the lower pressure setting.{{ref|abramov}}
The maximum length of time the suits may be used in a vacuum is 125 minutes. The time is limited because the oxygen flow to the suit is enough for life support, but insufficient to carry away the cosmonaut's body heat and longer use of the suit risks [[Heat exhaustion]]. If the capsule becomes depressurised, either accidentally or deliberately to extinguish a fire, it must land within that time.<ref name="ESA">{{Cite video |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oE5Z3Uxbezc |title=Fire in the Soyuz! |date=May 18, 2015 |publisher=European Space Agency }}</ref>
== History == Pressure suits were worn on the [[Vostok program|Vostok]] space missions, but when the Soyuz spacecraft was being developed in the mid-1960s, the controversial decision was taken by its designers, [[OKB-1]], not to use them on the new spacecraft. Some of the early Soyuz flights carried [[Yastreb]] space suits but these were only for space walks and were only worn in orbit.
On June 30, 1971, the crew of [[Soyuz 11]] died when their spacecraft depressurised during re-entry. One of the recommendations of the investigating government commission was that pressure suits should be worn by future crews during critical phases of their mission - launch, docking and landing.
NPP Zvezda was given the task of providing the suits. They rejected the use of existing Soviet space suits and chose to base a new suit on the existing Sokol aviation [[pressure suit]]. The main modification was the replacement of the Sokol suit's hard helmet. Other features of the aviation suit that were considered unnecessary were removed to save weight.
At the same time, a life support system was developed in co-operation with [[OKB-1]]. The new suit was named the Sokol-K, K (Kosmos) is the abbreviation of the Russian word for space.
== Sokol variants == [[Image:SNC16515.JPG|thumb|200px|A Sokol-K spacesuit displayed at the Memorial Museum of Astronautics, Moscow (2009)]]
=== Sokol-K ===
The first version of the suit, it was used on [[Soyuz 12]], launched on September 27, 1973.
'''Name:''' Sokol-K Rescue Spacesuit<ref name=Rs>{{cite book |title= Russian Spacesuits |last= |first= |authorlink= |author=Isaac Abramov & Ingemar Skoog |year= 2003 |publisher= Praxis Publishing Ltd. |location= Chichester, UK |isbn= 1-85233-732-X |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=f7pZosHqkbEC&dq=S-901J+suit&source=gbs_navlinks_s }}</ref>
'''Derived from:''' Sokol aviation full pressure suit<ref name=Rs/>
'''Manufacturer:''' NPP Zvezda
'''Missions:''' [[Soyuz 12]] (1973) to [[Soyuz 40]] (1981)<ref name=Rs/>
'''Function:''' Intra-vehicular activity (IVA)
'''Operating Pressure:''' {{convert|400|hPa|abbr=on}}<ref name=Rs/>
'''Suit Weight:''' {{convert|10|kg|abbr=on}}<ref name=Rs/>
=== Sokol-KR === A version intended for use with the [[TKS spacecraft]] which was to be used as part of the [[Almaz]] programme. The suit was never used as the TKS never flew with a crew. Its main difference was that it was designed to work with a regenerative life support system.
=== Sokol-KM and Sokol-KV === Work on improving the Sokol-K began 1973, immediately after its introduction. The Sokol-KM and KV were intermediate models on which many of the features of the Sokol-KV2 were developed, neither was ever used in space.
To be donned, the Sokol-KM and KV split into upper and lower halves joined by zip fasteners. However, this feature was discarded in the Sokol-KV2 and the appendix was retained as a means of donning the suit{{snd}} it was thought to be more reliable than the airtight zippers the Russians were able to make. Other changes included alterations to the fabric around the joints, to improve mobility, and improvement of the gloves, to make it easier to operate the spacecraft controls.
The KM and KV also featured a liquid-cooled undergarment that would increase the comfort of the wearer by efficiently removing body-heat; other suits relied on the flow of air to do this.
'''Name:''' Sokol-KV Rescue Spacesuit<ref name=Rs/>
'''Manufacturer:''' NPP Zvezda
'''Missions:''' None<ref name=Rs/>
'''Function:''' Intra-vehicular activity (IVA)
'''Operating Pressure:''' {{convert|400|hPa|abbr=on}}<ref name=Rs/>
'''Suit Weight:''' {{convert|12|kg|abbr=on}}<ref name=Rs/>
=== Sokol-KV2 ===<!-- This section is linked from [[Space suit]] --> [[Image:Expedition Seven.jpg|thumb|200px| The crew of [[Expedition 7]], Commander [[Yuri Malenchenko]] (front) and [[Edward T. Lu|Ed Lu]] are both wearing Sokol KV-2 pressure suits.]] The Sokol-KV2, the current version of the suit, was first used on the [[Soyuz T-2]] mission, launched on June 5, 1980.
The main improvement was the replacement of the rubber pressure layer of the Sokol-K with rubberised polycaprolactam to save weight. The visor was modified and enlarged to give the wearer a better field of view. Laces in the outer canvas layer were replaced with zippers to make the suit quicker to don and the pressure relief valve was moved from the left abdomen to the centre of the chest so either hand could be used to alter the suit's pressure setting. The improved arms, legs, and gloves of the Sokol-KV were retained although the liquid cooled undergarment of the KM and KV was discarded.
'''Name:''' Sokol-KV-2 Rescue Spacesuit<ref name=Rs/>
'''Manufacturer:''' NPP Zvezda
'''Missions:''' 1980 to present<ref name=Rs/>
'''Function:''' Intra-vehicular activity (IVA)
'''Operating Pressure:''' {{convert|400|hPa|abbr=on}}<ref name=Rs/>
'''Suit Weight:''' {{convert|10|kg|abbr=on}}<ref name=Rs/>
== Foreign use == [[Image:Yang Liwei space suit.JPG|thumb|200px|[[Space program of China|Chinese]] space suit worn by [[Yang Liwei]] during the ''[[Shenzhou 5]]'' space flight.]]
The [[People's Republic of China|Chinese]] have bought a number of space suits from the Russians for use in their [[Space program of China|space programme]]. The suit worn by [[Yang Liwei]] on ''[[Shenzhou 5]]'', the first manned Chinese space flight, closely resembles a Sokol-KV2 suit, but it is believed to be a Chinese-made version rather than an actual Russian suit. Pictures show that the suits worn by [[Fei Junlong]] and [[Nie Haisheng]] on ''[[Shenzhou 6]]'' differ in detail from the earlier suit; they are also reported to be lighter.
Sokol suits have been bought for uses other than spaceflight. It was planned that the crew of the [[Great Britain|British]] [[QinetiQ 1]] high-altitude balloon would wear modified Sokol suits purchased from [[NPP Zvezda|Zvezda]]. As the balloonists would have occupied an open platform during their twelve-hour flight, the Sokol suits, together with heavily insulated outer garments, would have protected them from the cold and low pressure of the [[stratosphere]] as the balloon ascended to a height of around 40 km (25 miles, 132,000 feet).
[[Bulgaria]] developed its own version of the space suit in the mid-1970s.
== U.S. equivalent == During the flight of [[Gemini 7]], [[Frank Borman]] and [[Jim Lovell]] wore modified Gemini spacesuits that somewhat resemble the Sokol suits, but with significant differences. Their suits were known as the '''[[Gemini Spacesuit|G5C]]''' by their manufacturer, the [[David Clark Company]].
== Collectors' market == Sokol space suits, including ones flown in space, were first sold by [[Sotheby's]] at an auction devoted to Russian space history in 1993. Subsequently, components such as gloves, communications caps, and wrist mirrors have frequently come up for sale on [[eBay]]; even complete suits have occasionally come up for sale, such as the one that [[Heritage Auctions]] sold for US$31,070 in 2009.<ref>[http://historical.ha.com/common/view_item.php?Sale_No=6033&Lot_No=41208] Talgat Musabayev Space-flown Sokol KV-2 Pressurized Spacesuit</ref> These are usually worn out items that have been discarded after use during ground training and were never intended for use in space. As these items are nominally the property of the Russian government, the legitimacy of their sale has been questioned.<ref>Stuart (2005)</ref>
== See also == * [[Space suit]] * [[Orlan space suit]] * [[Manned Maneuvering Unit]]
== References == ;Citations <references/> ;Bibliography * {{note|abramov}}Isaak P. Abramov, A. Ingemar Skoog, (2003). ''Russian Space Suits'': Springer-Praxsis. {{ISBN|1-85233-732-X}}. * {{note|sharman}}[[Helen Sharman]] Christopher Priest, (1993). ''Seize the Moment'', Gollancz. {{ISBN|0-575-05628-2}}. * {{note|wired}}Christopher S. Stuart, {{cite web | title=Psst - Wanna Buy a Slightly Used Soviet Space Suit?| work=Wired Magazine, issue 13.04, April 2005| url=https://www.wired.com/wired/archive/13.04/space_pr.html | accessdate=February 17, 2006}} * {{note|sotherbys1}}Sotheby's Catalogue - ''Russian Space History'', sale 6516, December 11, 1993. * {{note|sotherbys2}}Sotheby's Catalogue - ''Russian Space History'', sale 6753, March 16, 1996.
== External links == {{Commonscat|Sokol (spacesuit)}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051129085757/http://www.zvezda-npp.ru/english/00.htm NPP Zvezda's web site] * [http://spaceflight.nasa.gov/living/spacewear/ NASA's guide to the clothing of International Space Station crewmembers.]
{{space suit}}

/* Active and latent failures */ Fix spelling of attempt
revision.text:
[[File:Swiss cheese model of accident causation.png|thumb|right|upright=1.5|The Swiss cheese model of accident causation illustrates that, although many layers of defense lie between hazards and accidents, there are flaws in each layer that, if aligned, can allow the accident to occur.]] The '''Swiss cheese model''' of accident causation is a model used in [[Risk analysis (engineering)|risk analysis]] and [[risk management]], including [[aviation safety]], [[engineering]], [[healthcare]], emergency service organizations, and as the principle behind [[layered security]], as used in [[computer security]] and [[Defense in depth (computing)|defense in depth]]. It likens human systems to multiple slices of [[swiss cheese]], stacked side by side, in which the risk of a threat becoming a reality is mitigated by the differing layers and types of defenses which are "layered" behind each other. Therefore, in theory, lapses and weaknesses in one defense do not allow a risk to materialize, since other defenses also exist, to prevent a [[single point of failure]]. The model was originally formally propounded by Dante Orlandella and James T. Reason of the [[University of Manchester]],{{sfn|Reason|1990}} and has since gained widespread acceptance. It is sometimes called the '''cumulative act effect'''.
Although the Swiss cheese model is respected and considered to be a useful method of relating concepts, it has been subject to criticism that it is used too broadly, and without enough other models or support.<ref name="eurocontrol">{{cite web| publisher=Eurocontrol| title=Revisiting the Swiss cheese model of accidents| date= October 2006| url=http://www.eurocontrol.int/eec/gallery/content/public/document/eec/report/2006/017_Swiss_Cheese_Model.pdf}}</ref>
==Failure domains== Reason hypothesized that most accidents can be traced to one or more of four failure domains: organizational influences, supervision, preconditions, and specific acts.<ref>1. J.A. Doran (Shell International Exploration and Production B.V.) |G.C. van der Graaf (Shell International Exploration and Production B.V.) Tripod-BETA: Incident investigation and analysis, Proceedings of the SPEE Health, Safety and Environment in Oil and Gas Exploration and Production Conference, 9-12 June, New Orleans, Louisiana Publication Date1996</ref><ref>2. A.D. Gower-Jones (Shell International Exploration and Production) | G.C. van der Graf (Shell International Exploration and Production) Experience with Tripod BETA Incident Analysis Proceedings of the SPE International Conference on Health, Safety, and Environment in Oil and Gas Exploration and Production, 7-10 June, Caracas, Venezuela Publication Date1998</ref>For example, in aviation, preconditions for unsafe acts include fatigued air crew or improper communications practices. Unsafe supervision encompasses for example, pairing inexperienced pilots on a night flight into known adverse weather. Organizational influences encompass such things as reduction in expenditure on pilot training in times of financial austerity.<ref name=Wieg/><ref name=Stranks />
==Holes and slices== In the Swiss cheese model, an organisation's defenses against failure are modeled as a series of barriers, represented as slices of cheese. The holes in the slices represent weaknesses in individual parts of the system and are continually varying in size and position across the slices. The system produces failures when a hole in each slice momentarily aligns, permitting (in Reason's words) "a trajectory of accident opportunity", so that a hazard passes through holes in all of the slices, leading to a failure.<ref>{{cite book|title=Controlling Pilot Error|author1=Daryl Raymond Smith |author2=David Frazier |author3=L W Reithmaier |author4=James C Miller |last-author-amp=yes |pages=10|year=2001|publisher=McGraw-Hill Professional|isbn=0071373187}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|pages=4–6|title=Clinical Risk Management in Midwifery: the right to a perfect baby?|author1=Jo. H. Wilson |author2=Andrew Symon |author3=Josephine Williams |author4=John Tingle |last-author-amp=yes |year=2002|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|isbn=0750628510}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Clinical Governance in Mental Health and Learning Disability Services: A Practical Guide|editor1=Adrian J. B. James |editor2=Tim Kendall |editor3=Adrian Worrall |pages=176|year=2005|publisher=Gaskell|isbn=1904671128|chapter=Risk management |author1=Tim Amos |author2=Peter Snowden |lastauthoramp=yes }}</ref><ref name=Stranks>{{cite book|title=Human Factors and Behavioural Safety|author=Stranks, J. |pages=130–131|publisher=Butterworth-Heinemann|date=2007|isbn=9780750681551}}</ref>
Frosch<ref>{{cite book|title=Seeds of Disaster, Roots of Response: How Private Action Can Reduce Public Vulnerability|editor1=Philip E Auerswald |editor2=Lewis M Branscomb |editor3=Todd M La Porte |editor4=Erwann Michel-Kerjan |author=Robert A. Frosch|pages=88|chapter=Notes toward a theory of the management of vulnerability|year=2006|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=0521857961}}</ref> described Reason's model in mathematical terms as a model in [[percolation theory]], which he analyses as a [[Bethe lattice]].
==Active and latent failures== The model includes both active and latent failures. Active failures encompass the unsafe acts that can be directly linked to an accident, such as (in the case of aircraft accidents) a [[navigation]] error. Latent failures include contributory factors that may lie dormant for days, weeks, or months until they contribute to the accident. Latent failures span the first three domains of failure in Reason's model.<ref name=Wieg>{{cite book|title=A human error approach to aviation accident analysis: the human factors analysis and classification system|author1=Douglas A. Wiegmann |author2=Scott A. Shappell |lastauthoramp=yes |pages=48–49|year=2003|publisher=Ashgate Publishing|isbn=0754618730}}</ref>
In the early days of the Swiss Cheese model, late 1980 to about 1992, attempts were made to combine two theories: James Reason multi-layer defence model and Willem Albert Wagenaar’s [[Tripod Beta|Tripod theory of accident causation]]. This resulted in a period where the Swiss Cheese diagram was represented with the slices of cheese labels as Active Failures, Preconditions and latent failures.
These attempts to combine both theories still causes confusion today. A more correct version of the combined theories is shown with the Active Failures (now called immediate causes) Precondition and Latent Failure (now called underlying causes) shown as the reason each barrier (slice of cheese) has a hole in it and the slices of cheese as the barriers.
==Applications== The same framework can be applicable in some areas of healthcare. For example, a latent failure could be the similar packaging of two drugs that are then stored close to each other in a pharmacy. Such a failure would be a contributory factor in the administration of the wrong drug to a patient. Such research led to the realization that [[medical error]] can be the result of "system flaws, not character flaws", and that greed, ignorance, malice or laziness are not the only causes of error.<ref>{{cite book|title=Annual Review of Nursing Research Volume 24: Focus on Patient Safety|editor1=Joyce J. Fitzpatrick |editor2=Patricia Hinton-Walker |chapter=The intersection of patient safety and nursing research|author1=Patricia Hinton-Walker |author2=Gaya Carlton |author3=Lela Holden |author4=Patricia W. Stone |last-author-amp=yes |date=2006-06-30|publisher=Springer Publishing|isbn=0826141366|pages=8–9}}</ref>
Lubnau, Lubnau, and Okray<ref>{{cite book|title=Crew Resource Management for the Fire Service|author1=Thomas Lubnau II |author2=Randy Okray |author3=Thomas Lubnau |last-author-amp=yes |year=2004|publisher=PennWell Books|isbn=1593700067|pages=20–21}}</ref> apply the model to the engineering of firefighting systems, aiming to reduce human errors by "inserting additional layers of cheese into the system", namely the techniques of [[Crew Resource Management]].
This is one of the many models listed, with references, in.<ref>{{cite book|title=Enhancing Occupational Safety and Health|date=2004|authors=Taylor, G.A., Easter, K.M., Hegney, R.P.|publisher=Elsevier|isbn=0750661976|pages=241–245, see also pages 140–141 and pages 147–153, also on Kindle}}</ref>
Kamoun and Nicho<ref>{{cite book|title=Human and Organizational Factors of Healthcare Data Breaches: The Swiss Cheese Model of Data Breach Causation And Prevention, International Journal of Healthcare Information Systems and Informatics, 9(1)|author1= Faouzi Kamoun |author2=Mathew Nicho|last-author-amp=yes |year=2014|publisher=IGI Global|pages=42–60}}</ref> found the Swiss cheese model to be a useful theoretical model to explain the multifaceted (human, organizational and technological) aspects of healthcare data breaches.
== See also == {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Accident]] * [[Aviation safety]] * [[Chain of events (accident analysis)]] * [[Healthcare error proliferation model]] * [[Iteration]] * [[Latent human error]] * [[Proximate and ultimate causation]] * [[Proximate cause]] * [[Root cause analysis]] * [[Safety]] * [[System accident]] * [[Systems engineering]] * [[Systems modelling]] * [[Tripod Beta]] {{div col end}}
== References == {{reflist|2}}
== Further reading == * {{cite journal|ref=harv|journal=[[British Medical Journal]]|date=2000-03-18|volume=320|issue=7237|pages=768–770|title=Human error: models and management|first=James|last=Reason|doi=10.1136/bmj.320.7237.768|pmid=10720363|pmc=1117770}} * {{cite journal|ref=harv|journal=[[Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London. Series B, Biological Sciences]]|date=1990-04-12|volume=327|issue=1241|pages=475–484|title=The Contribution of Latent Human Failures to the Breakdown of Complex Systems|first=James|last=Reason|doi=10.1098/rstb.1990.0090}} (read online: [https://www.jstor.org/stable/55319 JSTOR]) * {{cite book|ref=harv|title=Managing the risks of organizational accidents|first=James|last=Reason|year=1997|publisher=Ashgate|location=Aldershot|isbn=1840141042}} * {{cite journal|ref=harv|first=James|last=Reason|year=1995|title=A System Approach to Organizational Error|journal=Ergonomics|volume=38|pages=1708–1721|doi=10.1080/00140139508925221}} * {{cite book|ref=harv|first=Carol|last=Bayley|chapter=What medical errors can tell us about management mistakes|pages=74–75|title=Management Mistakes in Healthcare: Identification, Correction, and Prevention|editor=Paul B. Hofmann and Frankie Perry|year=2004|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=0521829003}} * {{cite book |ref=harv |title= Handbook of Aviation Human Factors |first1=Daniel J. |last1=Garland |chapter= Organizational factors associated with safety and mission success in aviation environments| first2=Ron| last2=Westrum| first3=Anthony J.| last3= Adamski| pages=84| year=1998| publisher= Lawrence Erlbaum Associates |isbn= 0805816801}} — Westrum and Adamski relate Reason's Swiss Cheese model to Westrum's "human envelope" model, where "around every complex operation there is a human envelope that develops, operates, maintains, interfaces, and evaluates the function of the sociotechnological system" and where the system "depends on the integrity of this envelope, on its thickness and strength". Westrum models latent failures as voids within this envelope, and active failures as factors external to the envelope that are acting to breach it. * {{cite web|ref=harv|title=The Human Factors Analysis and Classification System—HFACS: The "Swiss cheese" model of accident causation|publisher=[[National Technical Information Service]]|first1=Scott A.|last1=Shappell|first2=Douglas A.|last2=Wiegmann|url=http://coloradofirecamp.com./swiss-cheese/index.htm|date=February 2000}} * {{cite news|ref=harv|work=[[Pharmacy Times]]|title=Sources of Error in Drug Interactions: The Swiss Cheese Model|first1=John R.|last1=Horn|first2=Philip D.|last2=Hansten|url=http://www.pharmacytimes.com/publications/issue/2004/2004-03/2004-03-7697|year=2004}} * {{cite journal|ref=harv|title=The Swiss cheese model of safety incidents: are there holes in the metaphor?|first=Thomas V.|last=Perneger|journal=BMC Health Services Research|date=2005-11-09|volume=5|issue=71|doi=10.1186/1472-6963-5-71|url=http://biomedcentral.com/1472-6963/5/71|publisher=BioMed Central Ltd.}} * {{cite web|ref=harv|title=Seeking and finding organisational accident causes: Comments on the Swiss cheese model|last1=Young|first1=M.S.|last2=Shorrock|first2=S.T.|last3=Faulkner|first3=J.P.E|url=http://www.aviation.unsw.edu.au/about/articles/swisscheese.html|date=2005-06-14|publisher=Department of Aviation, [[University of New South Wales]]}} (also available on-line [http://www.tc.gc.ca/CivilAviation/publications/tp185/2-06/Pre-flight.htm#Seeking here]) — a reminder that while Reason's model extends causation to latent failures, this is not at the expense of eliminating active failure entirely. * {{cite news|ref=harv|title=Just How Secure Is Airline Security?: The Swiss Cheese Model and What We've Really Accomplished Since 9/11|date=2005-04-12|first=John J.|last=Nance|work=[[ABC News]]|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Business/FlyingHigh/story?id=647547}} * {{cite journal|ref=harv|journal=The Rutgers Scholar|title=Evaluating the Effect of Technology Insertion into the National Airspace System|first1=James T.|last1=Luxhøj|first2=Kimberlee|last2=Kauffeld|volume=3|year=2003|url=http://rutgersscholar.rutgers.edu./volume05/luxhoj-kauffeld/luxhoj-kauffeld.htm}} * {{cite web|ref=harv|date=May 2006|title=Right? Left? Neither!|first1=Elizabeth A.|last1=Howell|first2=Mark R.|last2=Chassin|url=http://www.webmm.ahrq.gov/case.aspx?caseID=127|work=Morbidity & Mortality Rounds on the Web|publisher=Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111016120047/https://webmm.ahrq.gov/case.aspx?caseID=127|archivedate=2011-10-16|df=}} — the application of the Swiss Cheese model to a specific case of medical error
[[Category:Error]] [[Category:Systems engineering]] [[Category:Failure]] [[Category:Safety engineering]] [[Category:Hazard analysis]] [[Category:Aviation safety]] [[Category:Scientific modeling]]

revision.comment: Removed deprecated parameter(s) from [[Template:Div col]] using [[User:DeprecatedFixerBot| DeprecatedFixerBot]]. Questions? See [[Template:Div col#Usage of "cols" parameter]] or [[User talk:TheSandDoctor|msg TSD!]] (please mention that this is task #2!))
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2016}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:''TV Guide'''s 100 Greatest Episodes of All-Time}} '''100 Greatest Episodes of All-Time''' (1997) and '''Top 100 Episodes of All Time''' (2009) are lists of the 100 best [[television show]] [[episode]]s in [[Television in the United States|U.S. television]] history. ''[[TV Guide]]'' published both lists: the first, published in June 28, 1997, was produced in collaboration with [[Nick at Nite]]'s [[TV Land]].<ref name=TCOTCoH/><ref name=THLHMTAFMAT1RHSGO/> A revised list was published in June 15, 2009. The lists excluded [[game show]]s and [[variety show]]s, but included [[situation comedy|situation comedies]] and [[drama series]].<ref name=THLHMTAFMAT1RHSGO/>
==History and differences== About 25 shows from the original list were featured during a special week on [[Nick at Night]] on [[Nickelodeon]] and TV Land.<ref name=TCOTCoH/><ref name=YtT/> On the original list several shows, including ''[[I Love Lucy]]'', ''[[The Mary Tyler Moore Show]]'', ''[[The Dick Van Dyke Show]]'', ''[[Seinfeld]]'', ''[[Cheers]]'', and ''[[The Odd Couple (1970 TV series)|The Odd Couple]]'' had multiple entries, but none did on the 2009 list.<ref name=YtT/> The original list included 35 episodes from the 1950s and 1960s, while the 2009 list only included 10.<ref name=YtT/> Over one-third of the new list first aired in the twelve years since the original list, including 14 from the most recent two years.<ref name=YtT/> The June 2009 list included episodes as recent as the April 12, 2009, "[[Peekaboo (Breaking Bad)|Peekaboo]]" episode of ''[[Breaking Bad]]'' and the April 7, 2009, "Baptism" episode of ''[[Rescue Me (U.S. TV series)|Rescue Me]]'', while the 1997 list included a two-month-old episode of ''[[The X-Files]]''.<ref name=YtT/>
[[CBS]] was the original broadcaster of 35 of the 1997 list members, including both of the top two: "[[Chuckles Bites the Dust]]" of ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show'' and "[[Lucy Does a TV Commercial]]" from ''I Love Lucy''.<ref name=TCOTCoH/> Several television series were represented by a different episode in 2009 than they were in 1997. The 2009 top rated show was "[[The Contest]]" from ''Seinfeld'' although in 1997 the show had been represented by "[[The Boyfriend (Seinfeld)|The Boyfriend]]" (number four) and "[[The Parking Garage]]" (number 33), instead of "The Contest".<ref name=YtT/> Three of the top 10 1997 episodes were removed although the series continued to be represented by other episodes: "[[The $99,000 Answer]]" (number 6) from ''[[The Honeymooners]]'', "[[Thanksgiving Orphans]]" (number 7) from ''[[Cheers]]''; and "Coast-to-Coast Big Mouth" (number 8) from ''The Dick Van Dyke Show''.<ref name=YtT/>
The 1997 list included detailed show descriptions for all episodes, while only a select few were accompanied by more than a single sentence in the ascending order 2009 list.<ref name=YtT/> Only one of the thirteen contributors to the 2009 list was involved in the 1997 list.<ref name=YtT/>
==Top 10== {{Div col}} ;1997 list: # ''[[The Mary Tyler Moore Show]]''—"[[Chuckles Bites the Dust]]" # ''[[I Love Lucy]]''—"[[Lucy Does a TV Commercial]]" # ''[[ER (TV series)|ER]]''—"[[Love's Labor Lost (ER)|Love's Labor Lost]]" # ''[[Seinfeld]]''—"[[The Boyfriend (Seinfeld)|The Boyfriend]]" # ''[[The Odd Couple (1970 TV series)|The Odd Couple]]''—"[[List of The Odd Couple (1970 TV series) episodes#Season 3 (1972–73)|Password]]" # ''[[The Honeymooners]]''—"[[The $99,000 Answer]]" # ''[[Cheers]]''—"[[Thanksgiving Orphans]]" # ''[[The Dick Van Dyke Show]]''—"[[List of The Dick Van Dyke Show episodes#Season 5: 1965–1966|Coast-to-Coast Big Mouth]]" # ''[[The Bob Newhart Show]]''—"Over the River and Through the Woods" # ''[[The X-Files]]''—"[[Clyde Bruckman's Final Repose]]"
;2009 list: # ''[[Seinfeld]]''—"[[The Contest]]" # ''[[The Sopranos]]''—"[[College (The Sopranos)|College]]" # ''[[The Mary Tyler Moore Show]]''—"[[Chuckles Bites the Dust]]" # ''[[I Love Lucy]]''—"[[Lucy Does a TV Commercial]]" # ''[[Lost (TV series)|Lost]]''—"[[Pilot (Lost)|Pilot]]" # ''[[ER (TV series)|ER]]''—"[[Love's Labor Lost (ER)|Love's Labor Lost]]" # ''[[The Honeymooners]]''—"[[Better Living Through TV]]" # ''[[Mad Men]]''—"[[Mad Men (season 1)|Nixon vs. Kennedy]]" # ''[[All in the Family]]''—"Cousin Maude's Visit" # ''[[24 (TV series)|24]]''—"[[12:00 a.m. – 1:00 a.m.|Day 1: 12:00 a.m.–1:00 a.m.]]" {{div col end}}
==Reception== [[Paley Center for Media]]'s James Sheridan regretted the recent bias of the newer list.<ref name=YtT/> Hal Boedeker of the ''[[Orlando Sentinel]]'' viewed the original list as a triumphant result despite its conflict of interest.<ref name= TCOTCoH/> The original list was derided for omitting ''[[Bonanza]]'' and ''[[The Golden Girls]]'' entirely.<ref name=TCOTCoH/> ''[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]''{{'}} David Bianculli was critical of the original list, saying that many selections would not be on a more legitimate top-100 list.<ref name= THLHMTAFMAT1RHSGO/> He claimed that episodes chosen from ''[[Murder One (TV series)|Murder One]]'', ''[[The Partridge Family]]'', ''[[The Love Boat]]'', and ''[[Speed Racer]]'' reveal a lack of either maturity or perspective, while others showed taste and bravery.<ref name=THLHMTAFMAT1RHSGO/> ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' critic Steve Johnson complained that it was premature to claim that any episode of ''[[ER (TV series)|ER]]'' had established sufficient cultural significance to rank third on the original list.<ref>{{cite web| url= http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1997-06-30/features/9706300002_1_top-tv-cable-advertiser|title=Top TV episodes: The cover of TV Guide this week trumpets...|accessdate=March 25, 2012|date=June 30, 1997|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|last=Johnson |first=Steve}}</ref> Jaime Weinman of ''[[Maclean's]]'' complained that the 2009 list was composed of the most well-known episode of famous series, claiming that they were largely unexceptional episodes.<ref name=TG1EWHOL>{{cite web| url=http://www2.macleans.ca/2009/06/16/tv-guides-100-episodes-weve-heard-of-list/| title=TV Guide's "100 Episodes We've Heard Of" List| accessdate= March 25, 2012|date= June 16, 2009 |work=[[Maclean's]]|last=Weinman |first=Jaime}}</ref> He preferred the 1997 list, which he said was produced when ''TV Guide'' was a higher caliber publication.<ref name=TG1EWHOL/>

==Notes== {{reflist|40em|refs= <ref name=YtT>{{cite web|url=http://www.paleycenter.org/monush-youre-the-top-the-fickle-system-for-determining-tvs-greatest/|title=You're the Top?: The Fickle System for Determining TV’s "Greatest"|accessdate=March 25, 2012|date=June 15, 2009|first1=James|last1=Sheridan|last2=Monush|first2=Barry|publisher=[[Paley Center for Media]]|quote=Lists are made to provoke discussions and arguments, so curatorial staff member James Sheridan has some bones to pick with TV Guide about their recent ranking of "The 100 Greatest Episodes of All Time."|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110108091818/http://www.paleycenter.org/monush-youre-the-top-the-fickle-system-for-determining-tvs-greatest|archivedate=January 8, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> <ref name= TCOTCoH>{{cite web|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1997-06-29/entertainment/9706280292_1_tv-guide-nick-at-nite-nite-and-tv|title='Greatest Episodes' List: Questionable, If Cleverly Timed, TV Stunt TV Guide And Nickelodeon's Inspired Marketing is Sure To Spark Ratings and Debates| date=June 29, 1997| accessdate= March 25, 2012| last=Boedeker |first=Hal|work=[[Orlando Sentinel]]}}</ref> <ref name=THLHMTAFMAT1RHSGO>{{cite web| url= http://articles.nydailynews.com/1997-06-23/entertainment/18027263_1_tv-guide-greatest-episodes-tv-land| title=This Hit List Has More Than A Few Misses Alleged 'Top 100' Roster Has Some Great Omissions| accessdate= March 25, 2012|date=June 23, 1997|work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]|authorlink=David Bianculli|first=David|last=Bianculli}}</ref> }}
